bestBHT.bht: The parable emphasizes that God's grace is available to all, even those who come late and have remained idle. It illustrates the different periods of time and ages of the world, highlighting that God's invitation is not limited by time or circumstance. Despite the lateness of the hour, the day still offers room for those who respond to God's call. It's a reminder that God's generosity extends to everyone, regardless of when they choose to come to Him.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: One hour before the close of the working day; a most unusual hour both for offering and engaging.
Why stand ye here all the day idle?—Of course they had not been there, or not been disposed to offer themselves at the proper time.
Yet there was room, they also are engaged, and on similar terms with all the rest.
Albert Barnes: The eleventh hour - About five o’clock in the afternoon, or when there was but one working hour of the day left.
Archibald T. Robertson: All the day idle (ολην την ημεραν αργο). Extent of time (accusative) again. Αργο is α privative and εργον, work, no work. The problem of the unemployed.
John Gill: These different seasons of the husbandman's going out to hire labourers...may have regard either to the several periods of time, and ages of the world, as before the law, under the law, the times of the Messiah, and the last days."
The state and condition of God's elect, by nature, as it is the same with others, it is the same with them all.
Why stand ye here all the day idle? for being about the eleventh hour, the day was far spent, it was almost gone.
John Wesley: About the eleventh hour — That is, very late; long after the rest were called.

bhtAttempts.bht: The parable in this verse teaches us about the generosity of God's grace and his willingness to include all who come to him, regardless of when they choose to do so. It shows that even those who come late in the day and have been idle all day can still find room in God's kingdom. This concept can apply to different periods of time and ages of the world, as well as to the state and condition of God's elect. Ultimately, God's invitation is open to all who respond, no matter the timing.

The parable emphasizes that God's grace is available to all, even those who come late and have remained idle. It illustrates the different periods of time and ages of the world, highlighting that God's invitation is not limited by time or circumstance. Despite the lateness of the hour, the day still offers room for those who respond to God's call. It's a reminder that God's generosity extends to everyone, regardless of when they choose to come to Him.

The parable in this passage challenges the notion of fairness by highlighting the generosity of God's grace. It invites us to consider the different seasons of the husbandman's labor, symbolizing the various periods of time in the world. The parable also speaks to the state and condition of God's elect, emphasizing that all are invited to partake in God's kingdom, regardless of when they respond. It serves as a reminder that God's invitation is open to everyone, no matter the timing or circumstances.

The parable teaches us that God's grace is not limited by time or circumstance. It challenges us to reconsider our understanding of fairness and emphasizes the inclusiveness of God's kingdom. Despite the lateness of the hour, there is still room for all who respond to God's call. The parable also highlights the different periods of time and ages of the world, reminding us that God's invitation extends to everyone, regardless of when they choose to come to Him.

This parable reminds us of God's graciousness and inclusivity. It challenges the idea of fairness by showing that God's invitation is open to all, regardless of when they respond. The different seasons of the husbandman's labor represent the various periods of time in the world, illustrating that God's grace extends throughout history. It emphasizes that even those who come late or have been idle can still find a place in God's kingdom. Ultimately, this parable teaches us about the limitless nature of God's love and mercy.
